image.altText: an aerial image of emergency services responding to a traffic crash on a motorway

items.synopsis: Police allege five boys were travelling in a stolen Mazda when it crashed into another car, closing three of the four southbound lanes of the M1 in peak commuter traffic. Investigators believe three of the teens fled the scene.

title.children: Two teenagers charged over multi-vehicle peak-hour pile-up on the Gold Coast

image.altText: a close-up of someone using an iphone to purchase alcohol online

items.synopsis: With concerns about ease of access for underage and binge drinkers, the Queensland government has opened consultations on how regulations impacting the industry could change.

title.children: No ID? No worries: The lack of rules for alcohol delivery services in Queensland has many worried

image.altText: Close-up of man

items.synopsis: Ben Roberts-Smith has lost one of the most expensive defamation trials in Australia, and along with it his reputation. There are other factors that now need to be considered too.

title.children: Here's what comes next for Ben Roberts-Smith after losing his defamation battle and reputation

image.altText: Front entrance of Maroochydore Court House on Queensland's Sunshine Coast on November 26, 2018.

items.synopsis: Police charge a 24-year-old man with unlawful striking causing death following an alleged violent attack at an event on the Gold Coast.

title.children: Queensland man charged over alleged one-punch attack after 39yo dies

image.altText: A studio portrait of Australian Army nurse, Vivian Bullwinkel, in service dress uniform

items.synopsis: Vivian Bullwinkel was the sole survivor of a wartime massacre, but the full extent of the horrors she experienced is only now being told.

title.children: 'Tortured and raped': The darker horrors of a WWII massacre revealed

image.altText: A man in a short-sleeved blue shirt holds open a barred door leading to a dark, debris-littered room

items.synopsis: In a basement in a Ukrainian village on the Russian border, the remnants of a torture chamber tell a horrifying tale. Those investigating what happened here say the depraved orders came from the top. WARNING: Readers might find the details in this story distressing.

title.children: When Russians came looking for Vyacheslav, he had already fled. So they took his mum to the torture chamber

image.altText: Fat, cholesterol and other substances build up in the walls of the arteries, restricting blood flow.

items.synopsis: Peripheral artery disease is described as a "silent killer", but women don't always show traditional symptoms, which is leading to underdiagnosis.

title.children: Danielle was given a choice — her leg or her life. She wants others to recognise the signs of this 'silent killer'

image.altText: An image of Billie Eilish singing into a microphone next to an image of Elton John in pink sunglasses and a dedazzled jacket

items.synopsis: North Queensland once hosted world-renowned artists Elton John and Billie Eilish within months of each other. Now it's being overlooked as the live music industry grapples with an uncertain future.

title.children: It has a $300m stadium and legions of fans, but this city is no longer attracting music royalty

image.altText: Yamba forensics

items.synopsis: Police are investigating the shooting deaths of a 58-year-old man and a 15-year-old boy in the Northern Rivers region of NSW.

title.children: Man, teenager found dead with gunshot wounds in Yamba home

image.altText: Anthony Albanese mid-sentence while gesturing with his hands, the background is out of focus

items.synopsis: Mr Albanese will give the keynote speech at the Shangri-La Dialogue in front of US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin and China's Defence Minister Li Shangfu.

title.children: Singapore's prime minister pulls out of meeting with Anthony Albanese after COVID test

image.altText: Four young children smiling and laughing

items.synopsis: Charmaine Harris McLeod, her two daughters, Aaleyn, 6, and Matilda, 5, and her two sons Wyatt, 4, and Zaidok, 2, died after their car collided with a truck near Kingaroy in May, 2019.

title.children: Inquest hears Charmaine McLeod claimed husband raped her and her children in years prior to fatal crash

image.altText: A woman is tackled during a rugby league match

items.synopsis: The opening match of the 2023 women's Origin series might have been far from the elite product we have come to know, but it was also proof that it is time for women's rugby league to go to the next level.

title.children: For the success of the women's Origin series to continue the game must be put in a position to succeed

image.altText: A large circular CSIRO logo on the side of a building.

items.synopsis: The payment error was revealed by Greens senator David Shoebridge, who asked CSIRO chief executive Larry Marshall about the overpayment during Senate Estimates.

title.children: CSIRO deputy chair David Knox overpaid by $200,000, money still unrecovered

image.altText: Unidentified woman looking out of her window.

items.synopsis: The neighbour of a Tasmanian woman who starved to death in her own home says the 71-year-old was let down by those who should have stepped in to help her.

title.children: 'Nobody cared to do anything': Suzie says she tried to get help for neighbour who starved to death

image.altText: Charlie Wade stands on a pier

items.synopsis: English backpacker Charlie Wade was surprised when a girl he met on Snapchat asked him to send a nude photo. Her next message left him in a state of shock.

title.children: Charlie is one of a growing number of young men falling victim to 'sextortion' scams — he wants you to learn from his mistakes

image.altText: Close up of Kevin McCarthy surrounded by media as he walks into the Capitol.

items.synopsis: Wall Street's key index climbs to a nine-month high as a debt ceiling deal nears congressional approval and amid hopes the Federal Reserve will pause its rate hikes this month. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Wall St gains as debt ceiling deal advances, hopes of Fed rate pause rise

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, welcome to another day of market action. There was certainly some sighs of relief overnight on US markets after the House of Representatives passed the debt ceiling deal struck between President Joe Biden and congressional republicans led by Speaker Kevin McCarthy. The deal suspends the debt ceiling until January 1, 2025, in returns for some limits on spending that are estimated to save around $US1.5 trillion over a decade according to the Congressional Budget Office. That deal now looks likely to sail through the Senate, given the US government some breathing space before it threatens to run out of the ability to borrow money again at some point within the next couple of years. Some key economic data was also viewed positively in light of the upbeat sentiment from the debt deal. Private employment data stayed strong and jobless claims remained low but, despite this, wage increases in the US moderated, raising optimism that the Fed can skip a rate rise this month and may even be finished hiking. "Unit labor cost data for the first quarter normally doesn't trigger a reaction. But it signaled a significant improvement," Edward Moya, senior market analyst at OANDA in New York, told Reuters. "The market became confident that, 'wow the Fed rate hike for June is pretty much not happening ' and confidence is falling for raising rates for July." US manufacturing data, including around input costs, was also weak, further adding to the case that price pressures in the economy are easing. Futures are now pricing in a more than three-quarters chance of the Federal Reserve keeping rates on hold when it meets in a couple of weeks. The benchmark S & P 500 index rose 1% and the tech-heavy Nasdaq 1.3%, with both reaching nine-month highs, while the blue chip Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 0.5% to 33,062 points. Stay with me to see how the Australian share market reacts later this morning.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Will shares break their ceiling amid US debt deal?

children.content: Good morning, welcome to another day of market action.
There was certainly some sighs of relief overnight on US markets after
the House of Representatives passed the debt ceiling deal
struck between President Joe Biden and congressional republicans led by Speaker Kevin McCarthy.
The deal
suspends the debt ceiling until January 1, 2025
, in returns for some limits on spending that are estimated to save around $US1.5 trillion over a decade according to the Congressional Budget Office.

That deal now looks likely to sail through the Senate, given the US government some breathing space before it threatens to run out of the ability to borrow money again at some point within the next couple of years.
Some key economic data was also viewed positively in light of the upbeat sentiment from the debt deal.
Private employment data stayed strong and jobless claims remained low
but, despite this,
wage increases in the US moderated
, raising optimism that the Fed can skip a rate rise this month and may even be finished hiking.
"Unit labor cost data for the first quarter normally doesn't trigger a reaction. But it signaled a significant improvement," Edward Moya, senior market analyst at OANDA in New York, told Reuters.
"The market became confident that, 'wow
the Fed rate hike for June is pretty much not happening
' and confidence is falling for raising rates for July."
US manufacturing data, including around input costs, was also weak, further adding to the case that price pressures in the economy are easing.
Futures are now pricing in a more than three-quarters chance of the Federal Reserve keeping rates on hold when it meets in a couple of weeks.
The benchmark S
P 500 index rose 1% and the tech-heavy Nasdaq 1.3%, with both reaching nine-month highs, while the blue chip Dow Jones Industrial Average climbed 0.5% to 33,062 points.
Stay with me to see how the Australian share market reacts later this morning.

image.altText: A woman sits at a computer with her hair shielding her face, drinking a coffee.

items.synopsis: International students say tools to detect AI-generated text are inaccurate, as a US study suggests the detectors are biased against people writing in English as a second language.

title.children: Chinese students say detector tools mistakenly flag original writing as AI-generated text

image.altText: A tattoo of a man in a bandanna on a leg.

items.synopsis: The WA premier's handling of the pandemic inspired tattoos and even a cereal brand, but what else will people remember him for, and what issues remain unresolved?

title.children: On Mark McGowan's last day as premier these are the decisions that helped shape his legacy

image.altText: Stacey Gaspero in her backyard.

items.synopsis: A local business in Tasmania began mowing lawns free of charge after noticing a lot of clients simply couldn't afford their services — for Stacey Gaspero, it may just have saved her from being evicted.

title.children: Stacey's garden was so overgrown she feared eviction — then a stranger stepped in

image.altText: An Italian male tennis player holds his face during a French Open match.

items.synopsis: In one of the upsets of the tournament so far, men's eighth seed Jannik Sinner goes down in five sets, while 16-year-old Mirra Andreeva becomes the youngest player to win a match in the women's main draw ar Roland Garros since 2005.

title.children: Sinner exits French Open after wasting match points in thriller, Russian teenager advances

image.altText: A woman looking at an iPhone XS

items.synopsis: Mental health apps have flourished in the gaps within mental healthcare. But the products are also exempt from regulations in Australia, with some experts concerned about user safety.

title.children: Mental health apps are huge in Australia, but we don't have a way of knowing if they're safe

image.altText: A PwC logo on the side of a building.

items.synopsis: By coincidence, the furore around the consultancy firm PwC is raging just as the National Anti-Corruption Commission is gearing up for its start of business on July 1.

title.children: A coincidence is playing out in Canberra, and a new player might have spotted its first target

image.altText: A woman stands in a stable, holding a horse.

items.synopsis: The intrepid rider and her friends have experienced prickles in their pyjamas, emu encounters and many other pitfalls as part of their horseride across Queensland. Now, all they have to do is ride home again.

title.children: Kylie has just spent 1,300kms in the saddle to raise funds for mental health support — and she's feeling 'pretty good'

image.altText: Vladimir Putin and Cyril Ramaphosa laugh together while seated in front of a row of flags.

items.synopsis: A member of the ICC, South Africa would theoretically be required to arrest Mr Putin under a warrant issued in March by the court, which accused him of the war crime of forcibly deporting children from Russian-occupied territory in Ukraine.

title.children: South Africa faces political dilemma over whether to arrest Vladimir Putin during upcoming BRICS summit

image.altText: Damage to a residential building at night.

items.synopsis: Witnesses say the three were killed by falling debris while trying to enter the shelter, in what was the highest casualty toll from a single Russian attack on the capital over the past month.

title.children: Kyiv mayor launches investigation after two women and child die outside locked air raid shelter

image.altText: Rory, wearing a school tie and blazer, holds a guitar.

items.synopsis: At just 16, songwriter Rory Phillips is challenging the centuries-old view that the strong, silent bloke is the epitome of Australian manhood.

title.children: Rory's using music to take on a 'toxic mindset'. This week, 100 boys' voices have joined in

image.altText: Spider-Man, an animated figure in a skin-tight blue and red body suit leaps through the air against a cityscape.

items.synopsis: Across the Spider-Verse serves up more variations on the character — and more dazzling visuals — than a spider-man could point his finger at. But it's not just eager to please.

title.children: Latest Spider-Man movie is a dazzling, inventive and often hilarious challenge to the status quo

image.altText: Josh Tongue walks in England kit

items.synopsis: One English cricket supporter put a 100-pound bet on his mates son to one day play Test cricket for England. 14 years on, that faith has paid off.

title.children: England Test debutant Josh Tongue nets optimistic punter $95,000

image.altText: Ben Roberts-Smith surrounded by journalist outside of court

items.synopsis: If Ben Roberts-Smith thought his reputation was in tatters before today, it's hard to imagine what state it's in now, after a Federal Court judge threw out his defamation lawsuit and ruled the most serious imputations made against him had been proven.

title.children: Ben Roberts-Smith tried to clear his name — it proved to be an expensive own goal

image.altText: Two cars are seen smashed at the scene of a fatal collision in Alawa.

items.synopsis: The Northern Territory coroner is examining the actions of police during a pursuit that resulted in the fatal crash that killed a woman in Darwin’s northern suburbs in 2021.

title.children: Police actions 'reasonable' during police pursuit resulting in fatal crash in Darwin, officer says

image.altText: A bald man with a beard wearing a blue blazer, tie and tan pants walks across a street.

items.synopsis: A South Australian police officer denies a claim that his "annoyance and frustration" got the best of him during an attempt to arrest a young woman in 2021. He is facing three counts of aggravated assault.

title.children: Police officer accused of assaulting drunk woman denies losing control of his emotions

image.altText: A boy in a red play tunnel.

items.synopsis: Jana Hunt's four-year-old son Harrison has autism and oppositional defiant disorder. The Sydney mother is worried she won't be able to find the right school for him to start at next year.

title.children: Concerns some schools are contravening disability legislation by not accepting neurodiverse children
